sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1 & 2 \\ -2 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 5 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$$

where the matrix A is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix}$$

In our case, the matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1 & 2 \\ -2 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 5 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, we have:

$$a = 3, b = -1, c = 2, d = -2, e = 1, f = 4, g = 0, h = 5, i = -3$$

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

$$\det(A) = 3(1(-3) - 4(5)) - (-1)(-2(-3) - 4(0)) + 2(-2(5) - 1(0))$$

$$\det(A) = 3(-3 - 20) - (-1)(6) + 2(-10)$$

$$\det(A) = 3(-23) + 6 - 20$$

$$\det(A) = -69 + 6 - 20$$

$$\det(A) = -83$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix is -83.
